awd_titl_txt: STEM Core in Central Maryland for Cybersecurity Education
awd_abstract_narration:
Community college students, especially those from underrepresented groups, face many barriers in their efforts to earn degrees in STEM fields. To reduce these barriers, institutions can implement creative innovations, moving away from isolated programs and toward cooperative action involving employers, high schools, non-profits, and others in the regional community. This project will implement such a strategy that was developed by Growth Sector, a non-profit devoted to opening STEM careers to students from low-income backgrounds and from groups that are currently underrepresented in STEM fields. Growth Sector's STEM Core curriculum includes accelerated mathematics and immediate immersion in technical subjects for first-year students. Student Support Specialists provide comprehensive assistance to enhance student achievement.  During the summer after their STEM Core Year, students are placed into paid internships with organizations planning to hire employees who have the skills the students are developing. 

The Community College of Baltimore County and Anne Arundel Community College will adapt and implement the STEM Core Year for cybersecurity students at both campuses. Both institutions will provide wraparound support through Student Support Specialists.  In addition, the Fort Meade Alliance, a consortium of 200 members (including companies and individuals), will support the summer internships for cybersecurity students who successfully complete the STEM Core Year of course work. Both institutions have significant populations of underrepresented students in STEM and recruitment efforts will aim to bring these populations into the cybersecurity programs. Fourteen community colleges in California have achieved promising results after adopting Growth Sector's STEM Core Year model. For example, a majority of STEM Core students who began in algebra, had completed calculus by the end of one academic year.  This project will provide additional insight into the possibility that the STEM Core model may be a transferable approach for increasing student success and diversity in the skilled technical workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.inst_name: Community College of Baltimore County, Essex

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Community College of Baltimore County, Essex

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to provide cybersecurity students the opportunity to proceed rapidly through required mathematics and computer-related courses and thus be prepared to complete their programs and be ready for employment opportunities in the shortest possible time. The focus was on enabling students ?especially those needing remedial work?to overcome barriers to success in STEM programs represented by college mathematics courses. Over the course of the grant, the focus expanded to include computer science majors. Accelerated math courses, student support specialists and internship opportunities were the means used to enable students to overcome barriers to success in STEM programs.

 

Two Maryland community colleges, The Community College of Baltimore County (CCBC) and Anne Arundel Community College (AACC) participated in STEM Core in Central Maryland over the course of 4 years (the 3-year grant received a 1 year no-cost extension). A total of 130 students participated in the program during years 2 through 4, the period during which both colleges had STEM Core cohorts. Throughout that period, the number of students from underrepresented minorities increased, as a percentage, from 53% in year 2 to 72% in year 4. The percentage of women participating ranged from 43% in years 2 and 4, to 52% in year 3.

a) Students registered for accelerated math courses provided at the community colleges. There were two accelerated courses offered. The first accelerated course combined Algebra II (a developmental course) and Pre-Calculus I. The second accelerated course combined Pre-Calculus II and Calculus I.

b) Student support specialists were hired (3 at CCBC, 1 at AACC) to provide wrap around support to the students. The student support specialists worked with students in workshops and met with the students one on one as well to assist in various non-academic issues that arose. At both colleges, workshops were offered each semester, covering topics focused on increasing student success in course work, obtaining internships and exploring career possibilities. Resume writing, study skills, career options, and networking opportunities are examples of some of topics.

c) Both colleges worked with students to identify and obtain internships. COVID restrictions severely hampered this process, especially in 2020. At CCBC an inhouse research experience/internship was offered during the summers of years 3 and 4.

d) AACC provided a Summer Bridge program in years 2 and 4 to give rising high school seniors from underrepresented populations, who may not have previously seen themselves in a STEM career field, an opportunity to build their mathematical foundation and explore STEM careers.

 

The program had 4 main objectives as outlined below with their respective expected and achieved outcomes:

Objective 1: Provide 3 annual cohorts of 45 cybersecurity students (30 at CCBC and 15 at AACC each year), one year of accelerated coursework in mathematics and immersion in technical subjects required for their degrees;

Outcome 1:  From years 2 to 4, a total of 130 students participated in the programs at the two community colleges, meeting 86% of this objective.

 

Objective 2: 50% of students will pass accelerated math classes and be prepared to take Pre-calculus in their second semester;

Outcome 2:  The average pass rate for the 3-year period (years 2 through 4) was 62% for CCBC and 69% for AACC.

 

Objective 3: Have 40% of participating students complete their STEM Core Year in good academic standing (i.e. with a GPA of at least 2.0), prepared for a ten-week summer internship and ready to continue their studies toward an A.A.S. degree

Outcome 3: The average (years 2 through 4) percentage of students who completed the academic year in good standing was 86% for CCBC students and 95% for AACC students.

The  number of internships for CCBC students over the 3 years (year 2 through year 4) was 20. 15 of those internships were part of the  research experience/internship, Hacked and Loaded. Hacked and Loaded was a cybersecurity research experience presided over by CCBC faculty. AACC worked closely with Fort Meade Alliance to identify a total of 6 internships over the 3 years. COVID restrictions severely hampered internship placement, especially in summer 2020.

Objective 4:  By the conclusion of the funded period, enable 40 participants to earn an associates degree in a cybersecurity field or be hired into career related jobs without having yet completed their degrees.[1]

Outcome 4: Only CCBC had any students the first year. Of the 33 students who participated the first year, 24 successfully completed Pre-Calculus II/Calculus I and, of those 24, 10 eventually received associates degrees. 


[1] This objective applies primarily to students who participate in year 1 of the project period. Some students who participate in year 2 may also complete their degrees, but year 3 participants will not have enough time to complete their community college education during the grant-funded period.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2022
Modified by: Michael Venn
